awd_titl_txt: The 2023 Gulf States Math Alliance Conference and Faculty Development Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
This project serves the national interest by working to broadening participation of students from underrepresented and underserved populations in the mathematical sciences. Specifically, this project will organize the 2023 Annual Gulf States Math Alliance (GSMATH) Conference and offer a faculty development workshop to support the use of collaborative mentoring strategies by mathematics faculty at participating institutions. The GSMATH Conference will be held at Texas Southern University in Houston, Texas during February 24-26, 2023.  The conference is organized by GSMATH, which is the regional mathematics alliance covering the states of Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi that includes an active and strong network of faculty mentors in over 25 HSIs (Hispanic Serving Institutions), HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), and other institutions that serve a diverse population of students. Building from six prior GSMATH conferences, it is anticipated that 125 students will attend the conference with an additional 25 faculty also participating in the faculty development workshop. The conference will provide multiple sessions centered on demystifying the pathways through undergraduate degree programs in the mathematical sciences.  Keynote speakers, panel discussions, a student poster session, and a graduate and undergraduate program fair will provide multiple opportunities for students to network, ask questions, and receive mentoring.  The faculty workshop will focus on equitably supporting students as they grow from 2-year and 4-year colleges into graduate education or the workforce.  

The GSMATH conference will directly contribute to efforts to broaden participation and promote equity in the mathematical sciences. This, in turn, has potential to improve STEM education and academic outcomes for students across disciplines. Panels like “What I wish I knew Before Graduate School”, “Math Career Pathways (Academic and Non-Academic)", and “Research Opportunities for Undergraduate Majors” will allow participating students to get advice from faculty and experienced peers. The involvement of community college mathematics faculty and students is a critical element of the GSMATH conference, as 2-year colleges are a starting point for many students pursuing bachelor’s and graduate degrees in the mathematical sciences. The faculty development workshop will not only enable faculty to collaboratively mentor those students throughout the year but will also address important issues in DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion), critical transition from CCs to four-year undergraduate studies, and from undergraduate to graduate studies. Faculty development will also strengthen connections between participating institutions, supporting the growth of a responsive community of mentors across the discipline. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of the HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs are supported by this program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF project " The 2023 Gulf States Math Alliance Conference and Faculty Development Workshop"  (DUE- 2204309; 05/01/2022 - 04/30/2024) at the Department of Mathematics, University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), was directed by a faculty team consisting of Professors Jianzhong Su (Principal Investigator, UTA), Phyllis Okwan (Co-Principal Investigator, Southern University), Roderick Holmes (Co-Principal Investigator, Texas Southern University), Tuncay Aktosun (Co-Principal Investigator, UTA), Theresa Martines (Co-Principal Investigator, University of Texas -Austin).

This project served the national interest by working in broadening participation of students from underrepresented and underserved populations in mathematical sciences. Specifically, this project organized the 2023 Annual Gulf States Math Alliance (GSMATH) Conference and provided a faculty development workshop to support the use of collaborative mentoring strategies by mathematics faculty at participating institutions. The GSMATH Conference was held at Texas Southern University in Houston, Texas during February 24-26, 2023. The conference is organized by GSMATH, which is the regional mathematics alliance covering the states of Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi that includes an active and strong network of faculty mentors in over 25 HSIs (Hispanic Serving Institutions), HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), and other institutions that serve a diverse population of students.

The keynote speaker for the 2023 GSMath conference is Dr. Juan C. Meza, currently a professor of applied mathematics at the University of California - Merced.  Dr. Juan C. Meza shared his experience in his pathway to become a mathematics professor and an outstanding higher education leader. He encouraged faculty and students to pursue excellence in Mathematics fields and to mentor more URM students.

Dr. Phil Kutzko, director emeritus and Dr. David Goldberg, executive director of the National Math Alliance also served as panelists and extensively participated the conference.

Dr, Padmanabhan Seshaiyer hosted the faculty workshop in 3 sessions.

  • Integration of Broadening  Participation Practices in Research and Education, facilitated by Padmanabhan Seshaiyer, George Mason University and Minerva Cordero, University of Texas at Arlington.
  • Building Sustainable Partnerships, facilitated by Padmanabhan Seshaiyer, George Mason University and Ian Martines, St. Mary’s University.
  • Enhancing Opportunities for Mentoring and Research, facilitated by Padmanabhan Seshaiyer, George Mason University,  Jianzhong Su, University of Texas at Arlington, and Edouard Tchertchian, Pierce College.

The conference program covered panel discussions on various aspects of Gulf States Math Alliance activities, including graduate school experience, discussion of academic and non-academic pathways for math majors, particularly data science as a new field, REU for math majors, the graduate application process, the Math Bridge to Doctorate program at UT Arlington, F-GAP and mentoring practices. There was a Graduate School Fair, many faculty and students are actively engaging with representatives of 14 graduate programs’ representatives in the conference.

There were 144 registered participant including  71 students,  73 faculty and staff from 46 universities, colleges, industry, government agency and organizations.  Among them, more than 65 students and 59 faculty and staff were from HSI/HBCU or from URM and other underserved groups.

Campuses from the southern border of Texas all the way to Mississippi were represented.  Faculty and students from community colleges in Texas and Louisiana joined the Gulf States conference and played increasingly significant roles in mentoring and participation. 

The annual Gulf States Math Alliance Conferences were previously supported by the UTA Math Bridge to Doctorate Program from 2017-2022.  In January 2023, The American Mathematical Society honored the Math Bridge to Doctorate Program at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) Mathematics Department with the 2023 Mathematics Programs That Make a Difference Award.  The American Mathematical Society news release is in https://www.ams.org/news?news_id=7106.

Intellectual Merit: This project provides participating students with opportunities to develop their full intellectual and academic potential in the mathematical sciences, and it gives them academic opportunities and mentoring that emphasizes critical transitions from community college to undergraduate program to a comprehensive PhD program and develops new knowledge for URM math student mentoring and readiness for graduate studies.

Broader Impacts: By addressing critical transitional issues for talented and highly motivated URMs from community colleges to undergraduate studies to doctoral studies, the regional math alliance will collaborate to bring an effective and impactful solution to help talented but underprepared URMs and other students from underserved institutions, which can be used as a national model. The project also provides strong mentoring for students and a supportive environment for Community College students and math majors in participating institutions. Through Gulf States Math Conference and faculty workshops it brings a large number of mentors and mentees together, fosters collaborations and disseminates participating institution’s mentoring work and student success.
